title: Practical One
text:
Find all rows in “airquality” that have missing values.

rows_with_na <- airquality[rowSums(is.na(airquality))>0, ]
as.integer(rownames(rows_with_na))

title: Practical One
text:
Part 3:
The cars data contains two variables: speed and distance to stop. Fit a simple linear regression model to these data, i.e. find the estimates.

x <- cbind(1, cars$speed)
y <- cars$dist

beta <- solve(t(x)%*%x)%*%t(x)%*%y
beta

           [,1]
[1,] -17.579095
[2,]   3.932409

title: Practical One
text:
Part 4:

Check that you get the same beta estimates as when fitting the linear regression model using lm() in R.


model <- lm(dist ~ speed, data = cars)
summary(model)


Call:
lm(formula = dist ~ speed, data = cars)

Residuals:
    Min      1Q  Median      3Q     Max 
-29.069  -9.525  -2.272   9.215  43.201 

Coefficients:
            Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)    
(Intercept) -17.5791     6.7584  -2.601   0.0123 *  
speed         3.9324     0.4155   9.464 1.49e-12 ***
---
Signif. codes:  0 '***' 0.001 '**' 0.01 '*' 0.05 '.' 0.1 ' ' 1

Residual standard error: 15.38 on 48 degrees of freedom
Multiple R-squared:  0.6511,    Adjusted R-squared:  0.6438 
F-statistic: 89.57 on 1 and 48 DF,  p-value: 1.49e-12

title: Practical Three
text:
Plot the function \(f(x) = \sin(x)\) for \(x \in [-2, 2]\).

xval <- seq(-2,2,0.1)
func <- sin(xval)
plot(xval, func, "l")

title: Practical Three
text:
Question 5: QQ-plot
Generate 1000 values from a \(t\)-distribution with 1 degree of freedom.
Construct a QQ-plot with 95% probability bands (envelopes) to check whether the above values come from a standard normal distribution. You can only use use rnorm(), but not qnorm, dnorm, pnorm, or R’s qqplot functions.

set.seed(500)
x <- rt(1000, 1)
n <- length(x)
x_sorted <- sort(x)

#generating theoretical normal order statistics using stimulation
B <- 1000
Z <- matrix(rnorm(n * B), nrow = n, ncol = B)
Z_sorted <- apply(Z, 2, sort)

#95% envelope
theoretical <- rowMeans(Z_sorted)
lower <- apply(Z_sorted, 1, quantile, probs = 0.025)
upper <- apply(Z_sorted, 1, quantile, probs = 0.975)

#qqplot
plot(theoretical, x_sorted, pch = 20, cex = 0.5,
     xlab = "Theoretical Quantiles (Normal)",
     ylab = "Sample Quantiles",
     main = "QQ-Plot with 95% Envelopes",
     ylim = c(-5, 5))

lines(theoretical, lower, col = "red", lwd = 2)
lines(theoretical, upper, col = "green", lwd = 2)
abline(0, 1, col = "blue", lwd = 2)








Check with:

library(car)
qqPlot(x, envelope = 0.95, ylim = c(-5, 5))








[1] 532 162

title: Practical Four
Practical Four
text:
Question 2:
Rewrite this code using dplyr and the pipe:
original codes:

flight1 <- flights[flights$month == 1, ]
carrier_vec <- unique(flight1$carrier)
carrier_dist_vec_mean <- numeric(length(carrier_vec))
carrier_dist_vec_sd <- numeric(length(carrier_vec))
for (i in seq_along(carrier_vec)) {
  carrier_dist_vec_mean[i] <- mean(
    flight1$distance[flight1$carrier == carrier_vec[i]]
   )
  carrier_dist_vec_sd[i] <- sd(
    flight1$distance[flight1$carrier == carrier_vec[i]]
  )
}
dist_tbl <- tibble(
  carrier = carrier_vec,
  mean_distance = carrier_dist_vec_mean,
  sd_distance = carrier_dist_vec_sd
)
dist_tbl[order(dist_tbl$mean_distance), ]

# A tibble: 16 × 3
   carrier mean_distance sd_distance
   <chr>           <dbl>       <dbl>
 1 YV               229          0  
 2 9E               476.       334. 
 3 EV               522.       294. 
 4 US               536.       553. 
 5 MQ               566.       223. 
 6 FL               691.       142. 
 7 OO               733         NA  
 8 WN               942.       496. 
 9 B6              1062.       681. 
10 DL              1220.       644. 
11 AA              1350.       626. 
12 UA              1462.       778. 
13 F9              1620          0  
14 AS              2402          0  
15 VX              2495.        98.2
16 HA              4983          0  


##rewrite using dplyr and the pipe:

dist_summary <- flights |> 
                    filter(month == 1) |> 
                    group_by(carrier) |> 
                    summarise(mean_distance = mean(distance), sd_distance = sd(distance)) |> 
                    arrange(mean_distance)
print(dist_summary)

# A tibble: 16 × 3
   carrier mean_distance sd_distance
   <chr>           <dbl>       <dbl>
 1 YV               229          0  
 2 9E               476.       334. 
 3 EV               522.       294. 
 4 US               536.       553. 
 5 MQ               566.       223.

 7 OO               733         NA

 9 B6              1062.       681. 
10 DL              1220.       644. 
11 AA              1350.       626. 
12 UA              1462.       778.

title: Practical Four
text:
Question 3:
Explain why the standard deviation is NA for one carrier, and why it is 0 for others. Demonstrate your answer using code.

sd_zero <- dist_summary |> filter(sd_distance == 0) |> select(carrier, sd_distance)
sd_na <- dist_summary |> filter(is.na(sd_distance)) |> select(carrier, sd_distance)

flights |> 
  filter(month == 1) |> 
  filter(carrier %in% c("OO", "YV", "F9", "AS", "HA")) |> 
  group_by(carrier, distance) |> 
  summarise(observations = n(), .groups = "drop")

# A tibble: 5 × 3
  carrier distance observations
  <chr>      <dbl>        <int>
1 AS          2402           62
2 F9          1620           59
3 HA          4983           31
4 OO           733            1
5 YV           229           46


The standard deviation for OO is NA because there is only one observation. And is 0 for AS, F9, HA, and YV because all observations are equal for each carrier.

title: Practical Four
text:
Question 4:
Using tidyr and dplyr where appropriate, construct a dataframe where the carriers are along the columns, and the rows are the average departure delay (dep_delay) flown by each carrier (carrier) in each month.

flights |> 
  group_by(month, carrier) |> 
  summarise(avg_dep_delay = mean(dep_delay, na.rm = TRUE), .groups = "drop") |> 
  pivot_wider(names_from = carrier, values_from = avg_dep_delay)

# A tibble: 12 × 17
   month  `9E`    AA     AS    B6    DL    EV    F9    FL    HA    MQ    OO

10    10  9.33  3.00  0.677  2.96  3.42 13.4   9.70 13.7  -5.10  4.48 NA

title: Practical Four
text:
Question 5:
Calculate the proportion of flights that were delayed (dep_delay greater than 0) but arrived on or before time (arr_delay less than or equal to 0).

flights |> 
  summarise(proportion = mean(dep_delay > 0 & arr_delay <= 0, na.rm = TRUE))

# A tibble: 1 × 1
  proportion
       <dbl>
1      0.108

title: Practical Four
text:
Question 6:
##Identify routes that have more than one airline flies

routes <- flights |> 
            group_by(origin, dest) |> 
            summarise(num_carriers = n_distinct(carrier), .groups = "drop") |> 
            filter(num_carriers > 1)
routes

# A tibble: 128 × 3
   origin dest  num_carriers
   <chr>  <chr>        <int>
 1 EWR    ATL              4
 2 EWR    AUS              2
 3 EWR    BDL              2
 4 EWR    BNA              2
 5 EWR    BOS              3
 6 EWR    BWI              2
 7 EWR    CHS              2
 8 EWR    CLE              2
 9 EWR    CLT              3
10 EWR    CVG              2
# ℹ 118 more rows


##For each such route, calculate the average arrival delay for each airline (exclude NAs). Find the names of these airlines.

avg_delays <- flights |> 
                inner_join(routes, by = c("origin", "dest")) |>
                group_by(origin, dest, carrier) |> 
                summarise(avg_arr_delay = mean(arr_delay, na.rm =TRUE), .groups = "drop") |> 
                inner_join(airlines, by = "carrier") |> 
                relocate(Airline = name, .before = avg_arr_delay)
avg_delays

# A tibble: 343 × 5
   origin dest  carrier Airline                  avg_arr_delay
   <chr>  <chr> <chr>   <chr>                            <dbl>
 1 EWR    ATL   9E      Endeavor Air Inc.                -6.25
 2 EWR    ATL   DL      Delta Air Lines Inc.             10.0 
 3 EWR    ATL   EV      ExpressJet Airlines Inc.         19.5 
 4 EWR    ATL   UA      United Air Lines Inc.            10.5 
 5 EWR    AUS   UA      United Air Lines Inc.             4.28
 6 EWR    AUS   WN      Southwest Airlines Co.          -11.2 
 7 EWR    BDL   EV      ExpressJet Airlines Inc.          6.78
 8 EWR    BDL   UA      United Air Lines Inc.            22.6 
 9 EWR    BNA   EV      ExpressJet Airlines Inc.         17.7 
10 EWR    BNA   WN      Southwest Airlines Co.           -2.13
# ℹ 333 more rows


##For each such route, identify the airline with the worst and best average arrival delay.

best_worst <- avg_delays |> 
  group_by(origin, dest) |> 
  summarise(worst_airline = Airline[which.max(avg_arr_delay)],
            worst_arr_delay = max(avg_arr_delay),
            best_airline = Airline[which.min(avg_arr_delay)],
            best_arr_delay = min(avg_arr_delay),
            .groups = "drop")
best_worst

# A tibble: 128 × 6
   origin dest  worst_airline        worst_arr_delay best_airline best_arr_delay
   <chr>  <chr> <chr>                          <dbl> <chr>                 <dbl>
 1 EWR    ATL   ExpressJet Airlines…           19.5  Endeavor Ai…         -6.25 
 2 EWR    AUS   United Air Lines In…            4.28 Southwest A…        -11.2  
 3 EWR    BDL   United Air Lines In…           22.6  ExpressJet …          6.78 
 4 EWR    BNA   ExpressJet Airlines…           17.7  Southwest A…         -2.13 
 5 EWR    BOS   JetBlue Airways                 6.87 ExpressJet …         -4.01 
 6 EWR    BWI   ExpressJet Airlines…           20.1  Southwest A…          5.95 
 7 EWR    CHS   ExpressJet Airlines…           16.2  United Air …        -14    
 8 EWR    CLE   United Air Lines In…            5.97 ExpressJet …         -3.71 
 9 EWR    CLT   ExpressJet Airlines…           20.5  US Airways …          0.920
10 EWR    CVG   ExpressJet Airlines…           21.2  Endeavor Ai…          1.40 
# ℹ 118 more rows


##Identify the route with the greatest difference between the best and worst performing airlines.

greatest_diff <- best_worst |> 
  group_by(origin, dest) |>
  mutate(diff = worst_arr_delay - best_arr_delay) |> 
  arrange(desc(diff))
head(greatest_diff, n=1)

# A tibble: 1 × 7
# Groups:   origin, dest [1]
  origin dest  worst_airline   worst_arr_delay best_airline best_arr_delay  diff
  <chr>  <chr> <chr>                     <dbl> <chr>                 <dbl> <dbl>
1 JFK    ATL   ExpressJet Air…             128 Endeavor Ai…           1.40  127.


##Determine the reason for this difference

flights |> 
  filter(origin == "JFK", dest == "ATL") |> 
  group_by(carrier) %>%
  summarise(num_flights = n(),avg_dep_delay = mean(dep_delay, na.rm = TRUE), avg_arr_delay = mean(arr_delay, na.rm = TRUE)) |> 
  left_join(airlines, by = "carrier") |> 
  relocate(carrier, name)

# A tibble: 3 × 5
  carrier name                     num_flights avg_dep_delay avg_arr_delay
  <chr>   <chr>                          <int>         <dbl>         <dbl>
1 9E      Endeavor Air Inc.                 55          1.47          1.40
2 DL      Delta Air Lines Inc.            1874         10.7           6.34
3 EV      ExpressJet Airlines Inc.           1        124           128   


ExpressJet Airlines Inc. has only flown once on this route, from JFK to ATL, and this large difference is due to it being delayed by 2 hours and 4 minutes whereas Endeavor has flown 55 times with an average departure delay of only 1 minutes. This is not a very good indication of whether ExpressJet Airlines Inc. is a bad airline since there is only 1 observation.

title: Practical Four
text:
Question 7:
Identify all columns with missing entries, typos and any other inconsistencies in the dataset below (load it just by running the code; created using dput command, FYI):
missing entries:

df |> 
  filter(is.na(height) | is.na(glucose)) |> 
  select(id, height, glucose)

# A tibble: 5 × 3
  id    height glucose
  <chr>  <dbl>   <dbl>
1 id_5     NA      103
2 id_8    157.      NA
3 id_15   178.      NA
4 id_20    NA       87
5 id_40   170.      NA


typos:

df |> 
  filter(gender != "male", gender != "female") |> 
  select(id, gender)

# A tibble: 1 × 2
  id    gender
  <chr> <chr> 
1 id_25 femal 


inconsistencies:

df |> 
  filter(disease_status != "healthy", disease_status != "diseased") |> 
  select(id, disease_status)

# A tibble: 1 × 2
  id    disease_status
  <chr> <chr>         
1 id_10 Healthy
